title: AI Copilot Skill Atrophy
context: Engineering teams adopt AI coding assistants (GitHub Copilot, Cursor, etc.) to boost productivity. Initial metrics look great: faster code output, fewer boilerplate tasks, higher PR velocity. But 6-12 months in, a different pattern emerges. The skills that made senior engineers senior — debugging from first principles, reading unfamiliar code, reasoning about system design — are quietly eroding. Developers accept AI suggestions at 60-70% rates without deep review, and the muscle memory of problem-solving atrophies from disuse.
hypothesis: AI coding assistants make developers more productive without meaningful downsides.

effects.label: Developers accept suggestions without deep review
Code output increases but quality plateaus

children.label: More code means more maintenance surface

effects.label: Dependency on AI tools becomes structural

dontIf: Your team is junior and still building foundational skills
You're in a domain where understanding the code matters more than writing it fast
ifYouMust: Mandate AI-off coding sessions weekly to maintain skills
Require explanation comments on all AI-generated code blocks
Track problem-solving metrics alongside productivity metrics
Rotate AI access so developers maintain independence

alternatives.name: Selective AI use
alternatives.note: AI for boilerplate only, manual for logic and architecture
